Vacuum energy and virtual particles only seem to baffle us with our notion of existence because of the use of the term 'empty' space. It is empty only relative to the existence therein of any 'normal'particle, but scientists (or most of them) has for quite some time asserted that whatever exists in the quantum realm, they are not simply particles. Instead, space is supposed to be filled with stuff they call 'fields', and particles are (at least according to one of competing interpretations) simply excitations or 'vibrations' of these fields. Mhm. These guys sound like experimentalists. Of course the virtual particles don't "exist", they are just features of the mathematical approximation we use to solve the Euler-Lagrange equation for wave functions in ordinary spacetime, and Sean Carroll knows that. In 1D space for example, these can be solved analytically and thus no virtual particles are needed. For ordinary spacetime, this is impossible, so we resort to perturbation theory. Feynman simplified this by illustrating the perturbative terms as diagrams. Later, people seemed to start viewing these mathematical crutches as graphs of actual physical events. As a result of this being an approximation, the calculations are limited in accuracy, flawed in the sense that they need to be truncated or else the diverge, and are unable to explain gravity in a quantum sense because it doesn't converge. I accept strange things like wave-particle duality in physics, but calling these diagrams real is a stretch. They are called virtual particles for a reason. They can't "pop into existence" if they never exist ever.

One thing continues to confuse me. Gravity is, according to Einstein, not a "force" but a curvature of spacetime caused by the presence of mass. Meanwhile, the inflationary model describes the Big Bang and subsequent evolution of the Universe as an expansion of spacetime itself. So it seems strange to now hear the acceleration of the expansion described as being caused by some kind of "repulsive" force or energy, when gravity is not reckoned in terms of gravitons or fields, but rather in terms of the geometry of non-space things in relative motion.

So my further question is, rather than ascribing the expansion of spacetime to the presence of virtual particles, why isn't it considered in terms of the spacetime geometry itself? Is "space" merely the absence of "energy" or is it something in itself? Furthermore, if virtual particles come in and out of existence in an X-particles-per-cubic-meter kind of way, doesn't this imply that as space expands, so the amount of virtual energy is also forever increasing at the same rate?

Back to the notion of dark energy or dark matter being related to the accelerated expansion of space… How can that possibly be intuited, since it implies that all the dark energy between here and the farthest object is in some sense "pushing them apart." Is this nonlocality writ large? Especially since the most distant objects are "receding" away from each other at a rate much "faster" than the speed of light. Again, this all sounds like an issue of spacetime geometry itself, and not energy or fields.

One last point. Is space "real" vis-a-vis two entangled particles at opposite ends of the Universe? If there is a non-spatial causal connection between the remotest entities, perhaps we should consider what we call "space" as something within matter and energy — a collectively-shared tidbit of information — rather than as something that energy and matter are "swimming in."

Food for thought…?

Being super pedantic, I'll mention that what Sean said near 4:05 is not quite correct (but nobody really cares).

1) While it's true that there's exponential decay from higher powers of alpha, there's factorial growth from the fact that there's a LOT of more complicated diagrams. Since factorial growth overpowers exponential decay eventually, this sum is infinite. In simpler sums, mathematicians can use Borel summation to map the sum to a finite number.

2) Each of the diagrams with a loop in it is actually infinite. There's a dodgy process called renormalization that deals with these infinities in a systematic way.

1:55 That diagram doesn't represent the probability distribution. The actual distribution has spherical symmetry for all orbitals. The diagram instead represents something far more abstract:

Take the 2p orbital, for example. There's an infinite number of solutions to the Schrödinger equation for the hydrogen atom for this particular energy level and this particular angular momentum. But all of those solutions can be represented as a linear combination of 3 orthonormal solutions. Those are the eigenfunctions of the wave function, which are represented in the diagram and don't have spherical symmetry. We say that the actual electron is in a superposition of those 3 eigenfunctions. To calculate the distribution for the electron, we have to square the eigenvalues corresponding to each of those eigenfunctions and add the results. But by doing so, we remove the asymmetry and get the same result for every direction.

For 2 electrons or more (ignoring spin), the situation is the same, but the eigenvalues are 90º out of phase (orthogonal). You can only do that for 3 electrons in the p orbital (6 if you include spin), because the solution is 3-dimensional. Note that the 3 dimensions are NOT the space dimensions we live in. For the d orbital, for example, there are 5 eigenfunctions, so the solution is 5-dimensional and we can have up to 5 orthogonal electrons (actually 10 because of spin).

Well, actually, I'm not that surprised considering how much modern scientists ignore the epistemology and the philosophical sense of what they are doing. Does anyone consider that we ever directly observed atoms ? Black holes ? Gravitational waves ? What does 'directly observe' even mean ? Right now, pretty much everything we do in modern science isn't directly observed in the sense that we don't look at the different phenomenons and see them with our eyes.

Let me tell you what I think : atoms don't exist, electromagnetic waves don't exist and quantum fields don't exist, not more than the phlogiston ever existed. They are all models that match the behavior of all things we know and these models let us predict some phenomenons with satisfactory accuracy. I don't think we would ever want to call them the 'right' way to see nature considering how many 'right' ways became the 'wrong' ways to see things in the history of human knowledge. But as David Deming puts it in his brilliant books about the history of science : 'blind to the mistakes of the past, modern scientists can only repeat them'.
